title: EUR Hits 1-Month Highs On U.S. Data, Brexit Optimism
text:
Kathy Lien, Managing Director Of FX Strategy For BK Asset Management

Daily FX Market Roundup October 16, 2019

Euro hit a 1-month high against the U.S. dollar today on the back of stronger Eurozone data, weaker U.S. data and Brexit optimism. The had been trending higher for most of this week with a large part of its strength driven by the prospect of a Brexit deal that would reduce uncertainty and remove a major risk for not only the UK but all members of the Eurozone. A deal is close with German Chancellor Merkel saying, “we are in the last meters of the negotiation” and French President Macron adding that a “Brexit agreement is being finalized.” An agreement should be announced in the next 24 to 48 hours and when that happens we expect all of the major currencies to rally – including the euro. The September high of 1.1109 would be the target but the rally could extend as high as 1.1150 if the market finds the deal favorable. While Eurozone data is still expected to worsen, in the very near term Brexit optimism and the prospect of a Fed later this month will be the main drivers of EUR/USD flows.

The same is true for sterling. traded higher for the fourth time in five trading days despite weaker inflation data. The pair reached its strongest level since May 2019 on the prospect of an imminent Brexit agreement. And while one was not reached today, investors expect EU leaders to piece together a deal by Thursday or Friday. The latest consumer price report shows that inflationary pressures in the UK have been relatively contained. On a , CPI growth eased to 0.1% from 0.4% and , prices stayed at 1.7%. are scheduled for release tomorrow and while we are looking for a further drop in spending, investors will continue to shrug the data off in favor of positive Brexit headlines.

Meanwhile the traded lower against all of the major currencies on the back of an atrocious retail sales report. dropped for the first time in 7 months by the largest amount since February. the decline wasn’t as sharp but retail sales was still negative. shot higher in response with Fed fund futures now pricing in 86% chance of easing this month, up from 72% yesterday. Spending is the back bone of the economy and the latest report gives the doves their strongest reason to back a third rate cut this year. According to the Fed’s , businesses see expansion but many have cut their outlook. With that said, they report that the economy expanded at a slight-to-modest pace with tight labor market and rising wages. Fed Presidents and spoke today and the former seems more skeptical of a rate cut than the latter although Evans also feels that the economic data seems pretty good and the economy is navigating risks fairly well. Although , and other major currencies outperformed the greenback today, the losses in were limited despite weak data. Looking at the charts, USD/JPY is due for a correction, especially as we get closer to October's Fed meeting. Tomorrow’s and are not expected to have much impact on the greenback but the could ignite some movements.

The was the only currency to underperform the greenback. Even though CPI growth accelerated in the , the rate slowed to 1.5% from 1.7%. The market is looking for one more from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand this year and NZD is weakening because the data reinforces their expectations. In contrast, investors do not expect the Bank of Canada to ease this year, which explains why the currency completely shrugged off the softer inflation report. CPI fell -0.4% in with the rate holding steady at 1.9% instead of accelerating to 2.1% like economists anticipated. The is in focus tonight with scheduled for release. The RBA pulled the trigger on easing earlier this month and think tonight’s report will justify their decision. AUD/USD remains under pressure with 68 and 67 cents the key levels to watch.
